Situation1: They support a mentee facing a high-stakes project that could determine their future career trajectory.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Hand-delivering a high-value or sensitive package directly to the recipient and verifying their identity
Story: I glanced at my phone, heart pounding. My mentee, Sarah, had just messaged: “Can you review my project one last time before the meeting? I’m so nervous.” I knew how much this meant to her—her whole future at the company might hinge on this presentation. As her mentor, I wanted to be there, to encourage her, to help her polish those final details and boost her confidence. But the insulated package in my hands reminded me of my other responsibility. The address was across town, and the client had insisted on a precise delivery window. The contents were valuable, and my supervisor had stressed the importance of verifying the recipient’s ID in person. If I missed the window, the consequences could be serious—lost trust, maybe even my job. I stared at the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. Sarah’s anxious face flashed in my mind, but so did the stern warning from my boss. My hands trembled as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once, torn between supporting someone’s dreams and fulfilling a promise I couldn’t break.
